symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Depression (Major Depressive Disorder or Persistent Depressive Disorder)
Drug adverse reaction (e.g., to ACE inhibitors for angioedema, or opioids for constipation and irritability)
Side effects of medications (e.g., iron supplements for constipation,  some pain medications for constipation and irritability)
Electrolyte imbalance (e.g., hypercalcemia can cause constipation and irritability)
Uremia (a complication of chronic kidney disease that can cause all the listed symptoms)
Dehydration (can cause constipation and irritability, and worsen kidney function)
Hypothyroidism (can cause constipation, irritability, and oral pain in some cases)
Multiple myeloma (can cause hypercalcemia, leading to constipation, irritability, and kidney problems)
Amyloidosis (can affect multiple organs, including kidneys, and cause a variety of symptoms)
Sjögrens syndrome (can cause dry mouth, leading to oral pain, and may affect other organs)
Psychological stress (can exacerbate symptoms like irritability, constipation, and pain)
Autoimmune disease (e.g., Sjögrens syndrome, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., irritable bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease)
Vasculitis (e.g., Behcets disease, granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Chronic infections (e.g., Hepatitis B or C, HIV)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) (Crohns Disease or Ulcerative Colitis)
Hypersensitivity reactions (e.g., drug allergies, food allergies, insect stings)
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)

justification: Botulism is characterized by descending weakness, often starting with cranial nerves, leading to dysphagia, diplopia, and potentially respiratory failure. Photophobia and ataxia can also be present.}, {diagnosis: Wernicke encephalopathy

justification: This condition, caused by thiamine deficiency, typically presents with the triad of encephalopathy, oculomotor dysfunction (including photophobia), and ataxia. Dysphagia can result from general weakness.}, {diagnosis: Miller Fisher syndrome (variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome)

justification: This autoimmune disorder typically presents with ataxia, areflexia, and ophthalmoplegia, which can include photophobia. Dysphagia and weakness can occur as the condition progresses.}, {diagnosis: Myasthenia gravis

justification: While primarily characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness, myasthenia gravis can less commonly present with dysphagia, ataxia, and photophobia, often in association with ocular symptoms like diplopia.}, {diagnosis: Brainstem stroke

justification: Depending on the location, brainstem strokes can cause a variety of symptoms including weakness, ataxia, dysphagia, and oculomotor dysfunction (potentially photophobia).}, {diagnosis: Multiple sclerosis

justification: MS can present with a wide range of neurological symptoms, and while not the most common, photophobia, weakness, ataxia, and dysphagia can all be seen in various combinations.}, {diagnosis: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome
justification: This autoimmune disease primarily affects the limbs, but dysphagia, ataxia, and photophobia can occur less commonly.}, {diagnosis: Infectious encephalitis
justification: Inflammation of the brain from a viral or other infection can cause a variety of symptoms, including those listed, but presentation is highly variable.}, {diagnosis: Brain tumor

justification: Depending on the location and size, a tumor in the brain can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including those listed, though this is less likely as an initial presentation.}, {diagnosis: Vitamin B12 deficiency
justification: While primarily associated with anemia and peripheral neuropathy, B12 deficiency can also cause ataxia, weakness, and less commonly, dysphagia. Photophobia is not typical.}
